Una opositora de Duterte liderarà la “guerra antidroga”
Leni Robredo, crítica amb el president filipí, rep un “regal enverinat”

06 Nov 2019, 22:08

El polèmic president de les Filipines, Rodrigo Duterte, ha cedit a la vicepresidenta del país i líder de l’oposició el control de les seves polítiques antidroga. A les Filipines la presidència i la vicepresidència s’escullen per separat, i Leni Robredo, actual ocupant d’aquest últim càrrec, és una de les poques polítiques rellevants que ha criticat públicament els excessos de la “guerra contra la droga” engegada pel president quan va arribar al poder fa poc més de tres anys.
Robredo va acceptar ahir l’encàrrec de Duterte, malgrat que companys de l’oposició adverteixen que el gest del president és en realitat un “regal enverinat”, una jugada electoralista pensada per debilitar la vicepresidenta de cara a les eleccions del 2022. La “guerra contra les drogues”, plantejada al principi com una campanya de sis mesos contra el narcotràfic, s’ha allargat tres anys i no ha deixat cap més resultat que un sagnant reguitzell de cadàvers, però és popular entre els votants filipins, segons una enquesta publicada al setembre. Tot apunta que el president busca posar Robredo, obertament contrària als seus mètodes, contra l’opinió pública.
La mateixa Robredo s’ha mostrat escèptica amb el seu nomenament, però ha defensat que és una oportunitat per revertir les polítiques violentes del president. “Estic en contra de la matança d’innocents, m’oposo als abusos comesos per les autoritats. Ell [Duterte] coneix les meves crítiques, sap que és el que penso canviar”, va dir quan va acceptar les seves noves funcions.
Guerra brutal contra la droga
Duterte, que va guanyar les eleccions del 2016 prometent mà dura contra el tràfic de drogues, ha liderat una persecució brutal que no només ha afectat els traficants, sinó també drogoaddictes, periodistes crítics, ciutadans innocents i fins i tot nens del carrer. Segons ONGs internacionals i les Nacions Unides, les accions promogudes pel govern filipí haurien causat la mort de 30.000 persones. L’Oplan Tokhang, com es coneix popularment la política antidroga del govern filipí, implicaria execucions extrajudicials comeses per la policia i per assaltants desconeguts, empoderats per la impunitat promesa per Duterte.
Per la seva banda, el president i membres del seu gabinet sempre han negat els abusos policials, i atribueixen la majoria de les morts a “sospitosos que es resistien a ser arrestats”. Fins ara només han reconegut la mort de 6.700 d’aquests “sospitosos”. Malgrat tot, durant la campanya electoral del 2016 el mateix Duterte havia proclamat obertament la seva intenció de matar 100.000 persones implicades en el negoci de la droga i de tirar els cadàvers a la badia de Manila per alimentar els peixos.
A les crítiques que li arriben d’Occident, Duterte sempre hi ha respost recordant els crims de la Segona Guerra Mundial i del colonialisme, i en una ocasió fins i tot va qualificar de “fill de puta” l’expresident dels EUA Barack Obama.
text:
An opponent of Duterte will lead the "anti-drug war"
Leni Robredo, critic of the Philippine president, receives a "poisoned gift"

06 Nov 2019, 22:08

The controversial president of the Philippines, Rodrigo Duterte, has surrendered the vice president of the country and leader of the opposition to control their anti-drug policies. In the Philippines, the presidency and the vice presidency are chosen separately, and Leni Robredo, current occupant of this last position, is one of the few relevant policies that has publicly criticized the excesses of the "war on drugs" started by the president When he came to power a little over three years ago.
Robredo accepted Duterte's commission yesterday, although opposition colleagues warn that the president's gesture is actually a "poisoned gift", an electoral play designed to weaken the vice president in the face of the 2022 elections. The " war on drugs, "raised at the beginning as a six-month campaign against drug trafficking, lasted three years and left no more results than a bloody corpse of corpses, but is popular among Philippine voters, according to a survey published in September. Everything suggests that the president seeks to put Robredo, openly contrary to his methods, against public opinion.
Robredo himself has been skeptical of his appointment, but has argued that it is an opportunity to reverse the violent policies of the president. "I am against the slaughter of innocents, I object to the abuses committed by the authorities. He [Duterte] knows my critics, knows what I am thinking of changing, "he said when he accepted his new duties.
Brutal war against drugs
Duterte, who won the 2016 election promising a tough hand against drug trafficking, has led a brutal persecution that has not only affected traffickers but also drug addicts, critical journalists, innocent citizens and even street children. According to international NGOs and the United Nations, the actions promoted by the Philippine government would have caused the deaths of 30,000 people. Oplan Tokhang, as popularly known as the anti-drug policy of the Philippine government, would imply extrajudicial executions committed by the police and by unknown assailants, empowered by the impunity promised by Duterte.
For his part, the president and members of his cabinet have always denied police abuses, and attribute the majority of the deaths to "suspects who resisted being arrested." So far they have only recognized the death of 6,700 of these "suspects." In spite of everything, during the 2016 election campaign, Duterte himself had openly proclaimed his intention to kill 100,000 people involved in the drug business and to throw corpses in the Bay of Manila to feed fish.
To the criticisms that come to him from the West, Duterte has always responded by recalling the crimes of World War II and colonialism, and on one occasion he even described as "son of a bitch" the former US President Barack Obama.
